🍫 Biscuits 

Finally, if it’s budget treats you’re after, Waitrose does a good line. 

Its own-brand milk chocolate digestives are 90p, compared with a pack of McVities which will set you back £2.30

🧀 Milk & Dairy

In Aldi, it’s worth going budget on dairy products.

Its 400g extra mature Cheddar at £1.99 is nicer, in my humble opinion, than the 220g block of premium stuff for the same price, writes @eleanorsteafel

🍝 Pasta

Sainsburys Hubbard’s spaghetti – at 40p for 1kg against – is bitier and has more flavour than the mid-range, and is a perfectly good alternative to the expensive stuff

🍅 Ketchup

 I’m normally a Heinz devotee  says @eleanorsteafel 

🗣️I am as surprised as anyone to report that Sainsburys value Hubbard’s ketchup is also worth a try, at 44p for a 460g bottle against £2.30 for a bottle of Heinz

⚡️Many shy away from asking their boss for a raise. Here are the tactics to use for the best chance of success
Are you planning to ask for a pay rise in the coming months?
Read the other successful ways to secure a pay rise from @stokel’s piece here

❓But how much of a pay rise will you need to beat inflation? 

The Telegraph’s calculator can help👇

3⃣Arm yourself with research

Pitching for a pay rise can involve citing numbers from outside your organisation as well as within it. 

Amanda Augustine of TopCV, which writes CVs, said:  Come prepared with third-party data on the market rate for the role you’re performing
➡️Quantifying any income generation you were responsible for, or savings you helped to achieve, will often make a more compelling case than warm words about company culture

2⃣Look at the bottom line

It’s also worth thinking about how you present the information. You need to demonstrate your case in a way that makes sense to the business – and that means looking at the bottom line

➡️However, be careful about how much detail to offer.  Avoid information overload when polishing your pay rise story,  said Ms Lordan. 

A plethora of reasons why you deserve more money can be less effective than a handful of points well made
🗣️ To secure a pay raise, craft a simple, memorable story that represents your performance over the past year  Ms Lordan continued

1⃣Polish your pay rise story

Grace Lordan of the London School of Economics said:  People are underpaid because performance is difficult to measure and pay is often determined by unrelated things
💷It’s one of the most difficult conversations to have – which may be why asking your boss for a pay rise is something more than half of us have never done, according to one survey

🧠 What we are talking about is defined by brain science. We have seen MRI scans that show trauma has the power to change how our brain looks  says Conti

Read more ⤵️

Words like  resilience ,  snowflake  and  stoicism  muddy the waters of trauma and can make us see it through a jaundiced eye. 

➡️It’s why Conti thinks it’s important that we see trauma as a concept rooted in science

Raised stress levels mean conditions linked to trauma exposure can include chronic lung and heart diseases, auto-immune diseases and even cancer, the latter more normally as a result of stress-induced behaviours, such as smoking, rather than the stress itself
⚠️In the short term, trauma causes an intense, biological  alarm state  including a rush of adrenaline, cortisol and other hormones as well as intense fear

Dr Conti, a Stanford and Harvard trained medic, argues that many of us are suffering from health conditions linked to trauma without being able to recognise the signs

🗣️ It’s not always a case of what doesn’t kill us makes us stronger’,  says Conti.

Our understanding of trauma has come a long way since shell-shocked soldiers returned from the trenches of World War One.

🧠A variety of studies have pinpointed the impact of trauma on key structures of the developing brain

At the point where she was hospitalised – having suffered from hallucinations during a world tour – she had no idea that her health problems were linked to her previous trauma. 

It was the subsequent conversations she had with Conti that allowed her to start to heal

🗣️The actress and singer has since been open about how being raped as a 19-year-old caused a trauma so profound that she was left living with fibromyalgia – a long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, sometimes sparked by trauma or severe stress

📅In 2017 a young woman was admitted as an emergency patient suffering from chronic pain to the private hospital where psychiatrist Dr Paul Conti worked in New York.

That young woman was Stefani Germanotta, better known as Lady Gaga

France urged to come clean about Exocet missile kill switches’.

🔓 This front page story is currently free to read ⬇️
⚡️ Falklands War: France urged to come clean about Exocet missile kill switches’

Mr Ellwood said the suggestion France could have shared knowledge about the Exocet that could have saved British lives  warrants further investigation 

🔓 This front page story is currently free to read ⬇️

According to a highly-placed source, France denied that the kill switches existed, but British officials became convinced it was not telling the truth, partly as a result of investigations carried out on an earlier variant of the missile that had been bought by the UK
👉 British experts believed the Exocets contained a kill switch, which arms manufacturers sometimes secretly build into weapons so they can be disabled if they fall into the hands of a hostile state.

🎯 The missiles were made by the French firm Aerospatiale and, as the Royal Navy task force sailed south to retake the islands from their Argentinian occupiers, Britain appealed to its ally for information about how they worked and whether they could be disabled

Three Royal Navy ships were hit by Exocets during the Falklands conflict, two of which – HMS Sheffield and the merchant vessel Atlantic Conveyor – sank. 

Sailors died on all three ships

🗣️ Tobias Ellwood, the chairman of Parliaments defence select committee, said the matter  warrants further investigation , while Liam Fox, a former defence secretary, said France – a vital defence partner of the UK – should be  open and honest  about what happened

📅 Ahead of Wednesdays 40th anniversary of an Exocet attack on HMS Sheffield – which caused the first British fatalities of the conflict – France has been urged to come clean about what it did and did not share with Margaret Thatchers government
🔴 France faces questions about whether it refused to share secrets about the Exocet missiles that could have saved British lives 👇

🔎 Did Russians really invent fish and chips?
Find out if fish and chips could really be a Russian invention here ⤵️
If the Russians did invent it, they didn’t really do much with the industry, did they?  says Andrew Crook, president of the National Federation of Fish Friers.

That hasn’t stopped the Russians doubling down on their claim.

And British foodies are not taking this battering lightly 👇
🗣️ But, he states definitively, dishing the fish up alongside hot potato chips – themselves a delicacy of Belgian or French origin – is, half a millennium on, an utterly British affair
That the meal’s origins are rooted in the Jewish tradition is  indisputable , says Panikos Panayi, professor of European history at De Montfort University and author of Fish and Chips: A History
🇷🇺 According to the Jewish Museum in London, Malin may have been born Joseph Malinsky; his Ashkenazi heritage rooted in an unknown part of Europe, possibly Russia

🔗 There is a definite link.

The first known British fish and chip shop was Malin’s of Bow, east London, set up in 1860 by Joseph Malin – an Ashkenazi Jewish immigrant
But even if Russia dictates the availability and cost of our fish suppers, can they really claim ownership of the initial idea? ⤵️
🐟 Our supply of cod-and-chips is under genuine threat from Russia, which controls 45 per cent of the global supply of white fish – and 30 per cent of the UK’s imports hail from that country

📺 During a television rant in which Isayev railed against our  evil  nation, urging UK-dwellers to  catch your fish and chips from your foggy marshes , the show’s host, Yevgeny Popov, chimed in that  white fish, fish and chips is Russian. 

Isayev agreed emphatically

🇺🇦🇬🇧 Its a culture war/actual war hybrid nobody was expecting.

However, the combination of fish and chips – according to pro-Kremlin minister Andrey Isayev – is not a British idea but Russia’s own

🍽️ The truth about Russia’s claim over fish and chips.

Its a beloved staple of the Great British diet but a pro-Kremlin minister says it is their invention. Does history agree with him?

🧵

⚡️There is more than meets the eye in Moscow’s muscle-flexing Victory Day parade, reports @DomNicholls

Overall, the equipment on display in Red Square was very shiny but largely out of date and not as special as Putin would want us to think 

Read about more about the military equipment present in Moscows Victory Day parade here 👇

3⃣Uran-9 unmanned ground vehicle

 Perhaps the most extraordinary piece of equipment on show on Monday was the Uran-9 unmanned ground vehicle. 

 However, with only around 20 in service, it is debatable whether the Uran-9 is a tangible military capability or still an experiment

2⃣RS-24 Yars system

 The RS-24 Yars is central to Moscow’s strategic nuclear deterrent and perhaps the only piece of equipment on show that is truly impressive (although by no means new)

✍️ The tank promises to be a very capable beast indeed. The three-man crew are contained in a special armoured capsule at the front of the vehicle and completely absent from the turret,  continues Dominic Nicholls

1⃣The T-14 Armata tank
 We were treated to a view of the T-14 Armata tank.  

 Yet another view, as it turns out, because this  new  piece of equipment was first introduced in 2015’s Victory Day parade and is so complex and... expensive, it has yet to go into mass production

🔴As mortgage rates rise, the cost of living bites and unemployment starts its slow upward march, the giddy heights reached by the market in the last decade may merely increase the size of the fall

Read the full story 👇

🏘️Longer terms mean lower monthly payments, at the price of more interest in the end.

One-third of loans are expected to run for more than three decades.

📈 This is increasingly common.

Back in 2005, the average first time buyer took out a mortgage with a length of 25 years and six months.

By the end of 2021 the average was almost 29 years, according to UK Finance.

🏠 James, 27, has just had an offer accepted on a £250,000 one-bed flat in Brighton.

To keep the monthly cost down, he has stretched out the term of his loan.

 I have applied for a 35-year mortgage, two-year fixed rate,  he says
➡️Buyers are now being forced to take matters into their own hands, stretching themselves to get a toe on the ladder before prices move completely beyond reach

📈Deposits are bigger than they used to be - savings worth 5pc of the home’s price were typical for first-time buyers in the 1990s, with 10pc the average by 2007.

At the end of last year, 14pc was the usual amount offered by those stepping onto the first rung of the ladder

💷 The average property last year cost 9 times the income of a full-time worker in England, up from 7.6 times in 2019 and 6.4 times in 2009.

Back in 2002, prices were a mere 4.9 times earnings

🏠 A typical terrace sold for £264,000 last year, almost 10-times the £28,016 the same home cost back in 1986.

Dramatic changes in price make homes look wildly unaffordable, yet buyers are willing to shell out - typically with the help of vast debts

📈 Across the UK as a whole, prices hit a new record high of almost £277,000 this month, up 79pc from that low ebb in 2009.

Over the same time wages have risen by 38pc - less than half as fast as homes.

The intensity of the predicament is clear

🏠 The Herberts struggle is a consequence of dramatic changes wrought on the housing market in recent years.

In the South East, where they are searching, the average property sold for more than £380,500 in February, according to ONS, up 12pc on the year

🗣️  Because supply is low, prices are ever-increasing. 

 I don’t see demand tailing off here a huge amount, even in the face of interest rate rises and the cost of living squeeze, mainly because it’s a Crossrail hotspot,  she says, referring to the new commuter line into London

💷 The 32-year old mother of one has a smaller deposit than she would like.

She and her husband had a flat, but it sold for a loss because of the cladding crisis - and high rents mean it is hard to save enough to keep up with rising prices

🏠 Katie Herbert is trying to buy a family home in Maidenhead, Berkshire, and has found herself out-bid at every turn.

 The market is mad here,  she says.  One estate agent told me a good house will sell in hours

💠Make time stand still

Feeling constantly short of time damages core happiness and health. 

⏲️But even the busiest among us can change our experience of time, making it feel as if we have more

💠 Treat yourself with respect

Having worked on self-compassion for several years, the voice I now hear in my head is exceptionally kind.

🗣️I realize my competitiveness came from a place of not feeling enough in who I was, writes @drchatterjeeuk

💠 Eliminate choice

Too much choice is likely to be a massive hidden stressor in your life. 

⏰By eliminating choice, creating personal rules and adding routine, you’re simplifying your life in ways that can transform both your health and your happiness.

❌Happiness can never be found in a world of wants, because wants are never satisfied. 

Instead, we should understand the things that truly make us happy: living in accordance with our values

💠Write your happy ending

🧠We’re raised in a Want Brain culture that fools us into believing hard work, career achievements and material possessions will make us happy. 

This is a cruel trick, designed to feed the market economy and keep it going, says @drchatterjeeuk

📈The single biggest problem people have in their search for happiness is confusing it with success, writes @drchatterjeeuk 

➡️Of course, it is absolutely possible to have both but is certainly not a given.

Happiness isn’t some impossibly distant destination or a state of mind reserved for the privileged. 

It’s trainable and accessible to everyone, writes @drchatterjeeuk

⚡️ Covid made the world go mad – Here’s what we know now about the year of lockdown
Read the full article 👇

Ultimately, Woolhouse says, Britain’s Covid failure was  a system failure… of not welcoming other ideas, not being sufficiently self-critical .

 The way that science, scientific advisers, officials and government interact in a situation like this is at fault. We panicked

🗣️  And I cannot stress how big I think that change was. 

 We suddenly started doing much more sensible things… making all these decisions that we should have been making, well, right from the very beginning

Policy suddenly began to move towards a middle ground mid-last year.

🗣️  From the point that Matt Hancock left, the Government’s approach shifted from dealing with this [as a] short-term emergency problem to accepting we were living with a virus

🗣️ We knew from February [2020], never mind March, that the lockdown would not solve the problem. It would simply delay it,  Woolhouse says, a note of disbelief in his voice.

And yet in government,  there was no attention paid to that rather obvious drawback of the strategy .

❗️ Come 2019-20, scientists were loath  to make complete fools of ourselves  by crying wolf again.

Drastic early interventions which could have made a difference, like closing borders, became unthinkable

❗️ Another pitfall in our preparation stemmed from our experiences with swine flu.

😷 Exactly a decade before Covid really did erupt to change the world, public health officials were warning that swine flu would do the same.

 Basically, there was a false alarm,  says Woolhouse

❗️ The first disaster was basing our pandemic preparation on influenza, says Woolhouse.

🎒 That was why Covid models included schools, which are key drivers of flu transmission, but not care homes – with catastrophic consequences

🗣️ British scientists and politicians were primed to respond disastrously to Covid-19 long before the virus was even heard of, epidemiologist Prof Mark Woolhouse argues in his book The Year the World Went Mad

💻 But since the web has blurred societal boundaries and opened doors to anybody with a broadband connection, today’s con artists have it easy.

🔴 While criminals have used deception and disguise for centuries, the grifters who currently dominate our TV schedules represent a curiously modern phenomenon.

To scam effectively requires patience, preparation, luck and no small amount of confidence

Whats more, people don’t seem to be getting much better at spotting would-be Walter Mittys coming

Grenfell’s single staircase prevented our families from escaping and obstructed firefighters,  said Grenfell United, a group of survivors and families of the bereaved

🔴 The Fire Brigade, however, has criticised the scheme.

It argues the design  does not provide suitable and convenient means of escape for all building users
The plans for Cuba Street include a staircase, two evacuation lifts, a fire fighting lift and sprinklers – while its external walls have non-combustible cladding

⚠️ The London Fire Brigade has called for more research on the  stay put  strategy, but warned that abandoning it would present  considerable  challenges.

Most existing buildings in the UK are not designed for mass evacuations, with no common alarm systems and narrow staircases
But  stay put  has come under intense scrutiny since Grenfell, where people were told to stay in their flats even when the fire became out of control

🔴 Most of the UKs high-rises are built to the principle of the  stay put  strategy.

In this strategy, residents should be able to remain in their flats in the event of a blaze whilst firefighters tackle it

🇬🇧 Even within the UK, there is variation: in Scotland, buildings above 18 metres require a second stair.

In England and Wales, office buildings above 11m must have two escape stairs, yet apartment blocks of any height need just one

🧑‍⚖️ Britain has some of the world’s most relaxed laws on escape stairs in high-rise buildings.

🌐 Second stairs are required in buildings as low as two storeys in Canada and four in the US, while in Belgium, Poland and Norway, it’s 25

Plans for new high-rises like the Cuba Street development have reopened a debate about the safety of the next generation of tower blocks, nearly five years after 72 people died in the Grenfell Tower fire

🏰 It was pitched as a new  castle in the cluster  for London’s Canary Wharf and would have created 424 homes with a public park at its base.

⚠️ Yet the Cuba Street tower hid what might seem a glaring omission for a 174-metre building: a second escape stair

🏙️The Canary Wharf skyline was due to gain another tower – until controversy intervened.

Last month, the London Fire Brigade expressed serious concerns about plans for the Cuba Street development.

It has since been shelved

🔴Vladimir Putin also sees Russian dominance of Ukraine as fundamental to Russian security

❓What does Putin want with Ukraine?

Vladimir Putin maintains that Ukraine is fundamentally part of Russian civilisation, both culturally and historically, and has questioned whether it is even a real country

A peace agreement signed in Minsk in 2015 stopped the worst of the fighting but has failed to deliver a settlement of the conflict because of disagreements between Kyiv and Moscow over how it should be implemented
The situation escalated in 2014 when Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula in southern Ukraine and sent troops to support a separatist uprising in the Donbass region in eastern Ukraine

❓What’s behind the crisis?

There has been tension between Moscow and Kyiv since Ukraine declared itself independent of the Soviet Union in 1991

Russia has also put forward a list of security demands including a guarantee that Ukraine will never be allowed to join Nato and that alliance forces pull back in Eastern European countries that joined after 1997 (MAP)

⚡️Myth busters: Was Sweden right about Covid all along?

Its too early to say who got it right.

But this is what we already know 👇

🔴ANSWER: Sweden

Sweden’s GDP fell by 2.9 per cent in 2020, while Britain’s collapsed by 9.4 per cent. Both have bounded back, but Sweden’s economy is this year expected to be five per cent larger than before the pandemic, versus about one per cent for the UK
🇬🇧🇸🇪Which countrys economy is expected to be 5 percent  larger this year than before the pandemic?

🔴ANSWER: Britain

As Sweden abolishes all domestic Covid restrictions, it emerges with one of Europe’s lower Covid death tolls: the rate is 1,614 per million people, just over half the amount of Britain (2,335)
🇬🇧🇸🇪Which country has a higher recorded death rate?

🔴ANSWER: Sweden 

Sweden had a drop in GDP of 2.9 percent , while Britains was 9.4 percent

Sweden didnt lock down... but people chose to minimise socialising themselves. 

🇬🇧🇸🇪Which country had a smaller drop in GDP?

🇸🇪Was Sweden right about Covid all along?

The country, which avoided lockdown, seems to be thriving while Britain is counting the cost of harsh restrictions

🔎Read the full report to find out how the miasma theory at the time of the Russian flu meant little consideration was given to social distancing or masks 👇

🗣️ You don’t get herd immunity with coronaviruses,  says Paul Hunter, an epidemiologist at the University of East Anglia. 

 When you combine that with the clinical evidence, the similarities between the Russian flu and Covid-19 are striking

Epidemiologists estimate that up to 60 per cent of the population was infected in the initial phase between 1889 and 1892. 

➡️But herd immunity does not appear to have been reached, hence recurrent waves of illness, marked by high mortality
If the Russian flu was due to a coronavirus – and it is an  if  – the Victorian experience does not augur well for our present

⚫️Four million people in England and Wales were ill during the first wave in the winter of 1889-90.

In spring 1891, there was a second, more severe wave.

The winter of 1892 saw a third wave, marked by a further 25,000 deaths

📸World History Archive/TopFoto

Though some of the symptoms, such as fever, chills and aches, were consistent with flu, an increasing number of scientists believe the Russian flu may have actually been due to a bovine coronavirus

📸Mediscan/Alamy Stock Photo

A severe wave of illness swept London during the  Russian influenza  pandemic of the 1890s. 

➡️The so-called influenza was blamed on Russia because the first reported outbreak occurred in St Petersburg in November 1889

😴Read our guide to a better nights sleep 👇

💊Vitamin B6 

This vitamin is involved in the production of melatonin, the hormone that controls the sleep-wake cycle. 

Most of us get enough vitamin B6 as it’s available in many foods, but it’s also easily depleted as a result of stress or excessive alcohol intake

🍞Vital carbohydrates

Eating foods rich in carbohydrates, such as pasta, potatoes and rice, increases the uptake of Tryptophan, an essential amino acid.

✅ The foods that help you sleep

🥬 Leafy veg & pulses 

These foods are rich in magnesium. 

Magnesium activates the parasympathetic nervous system, which is responsible for relaxation by binding to receptors responsible for quieting nerve activity

🧀 Cheese and yogurt

There may be some truth in the old wives’ tale cautioning against eating cheese before bedtime.

Cheese – as well as bacon, ham, aubergine and red wine – contains a substance called tyramine, which has been linked to migraines.

❌ The foods that harm your sleep

🍹Sugar, fizzy drinks & desserts 

Nutrition surveys have shown that adults eat twice the recommended maximum amount of sugar per day. 

Eating lots of sugar during the day can pull you out of a deep sleep

💤 New research shows that what we eat can have a significant effect on the quality of our sleep.

Rob Hobson, nutritionist and author of The Art of Sleeping, guides us through which foods harm and which help your sleep – and why

😴As a sleep-deprived nation, where one in three of us suffers from poor sleep, we will do anything for some decent shuteye.

Until the start of the Second World War, dinosaurs fascinated the British. 

➡️Our interest seems to have waned after that, until the mid-1990s, when our interest in these primal and often terrifying beasts was reignited

The UK has a long historical association with fossil-hunting and palaeontology.

🔴Avoid regular sugar boosts

Astonishingly, certain neurons in the brain feel a sudden rise in glucose levels (a sugar rush)

🔴Fast intermittently

Intermittent fasting supports the mitochondrial network by removing damaged mitochondria

🔴Lower your calorie intake (but not your intake of nutrients)

This reduces the output of reactive oxygen species which drive inflammation and cellular damage

Read the full long read here 👇

In recent years, Apple seems to have become uneasy with its crown  writes @iododds 

Having spent the past decade and a half making so many people so thoroughly dependent on its devices, Apple now faces a perhaps even bigger challenge: taming the forces it unleashed

Gloria Mark points out how much of our phone use is reinforced, even mandated, by social conventions:

📩 From the expectation that we’ll check emails throughout the day...

💬 To the common practice of googling to answer someone’s question during conversation

📱Almost every smartphone now has these features. 

Still, to Mark and Rosen, these are the fruits of Apple’s quest to make everything on iPhone feel fast and delightful, which shaped a whole industry in its image.

Apple’s home screen – with all your apps visible in a dense grid – gives you 28 reasons to be distracted on every screen (or 252 if you make every icon a folder of other icons)

I won’t say it encourages you, it makes you do it,’ says Rosen

📉Attention spans are short, crazily short, and they’ve been declining,’ says Mark

Some distractions are external, such as a phone call or a message

But about half are self-interruptions’, where something inside of yourself compels you to interrupt what you’re doing’
📱Rosen also cites nomophobia’ – a portmanteau of no more phone phobia’, meaning the unease we feel when our phone is far from our bodies
🧠He believes that for many people smartphones either produce or exacerbate symptoms similar to those of psychological disorders such as obsessive-compulsive disorder or attention deficit disorder

Psychologist Larry Rosen has worked on eight studies of smartphone use among young people, between 2012 and 2020.

📱He sees compulsive tapping and swiping in everyone from toddlers through nonagenarians to police officers directing traffic

♻️That was in 2017, several years on, the entirely rebuilt, communally run library has solar panels on the roof and a ground-source heat pump.

🗣️It was a brave thing to say, but I was right’ he says

Phase two, the villagers’ acquisition of the erstwhile part-time library and a conjoined mother-and-baby centre that had long since closed its doors, stretched into three years of meetings with Lancashire County Council officials, which drove Wilcock to the brink of despair

🏘️When Steven was a boy, his parents were always popping into the community centre – tea dances, whist drives, the luncheon club’ – and, in 2014, when the local authority offered it to the villagers for £1, he swiftly secured the approval of his fellow parish councillors

🗣️ Something had to be done or our community spirit might never recover

⚡️ Ambrose Evans-Pritchard: I didnt load the gun for the Capitol Hill attack

But it also needs a rebuttal because Gatehouse has the matter backwards 

Read Ambrose Evans-Pritchards full response 👇

💬 This episode invites a response, in part because it sheds light on the mental universe of the BBC...

 ...a taxpayer-funded institution accused by many of chronic ideological bias in breach of its charter

✍️ Could the BBC’s Gabriel Gatehouse not find better material than the ramblings of a superannuated Brit, who sheepishly agreed to give him an hour and a half on the request that he wanted to mine my memory for characters to talk to for his series?

🗣️ I had by then concluded that Donald Trump was a proto-fascist with the reflexes of Mussolini. 

 I thought he would try to overturn the election by any means possible, and watched with foreboding as the expected Putsch unfolded

➡️ But at the risk of spoiling a good story, I have to declare my interest,  Ambrose writes.

 I rooted quietly for Hillary Clinton in 2016 on the grounds that she was by then no longer the same political animal that she once was

💬 I loaded the gun a quarter century ago and laid it on the table, or so the BBC would have it...

 ...just waiting for the horned shirtless QAnon shaman to snatch it at the right moment, and lead the Trumpian mobs into Nancy Pelosi’s office
But no, apparently the violent convulsions of the world’s paramount economic and strategic superpower can be✍️ traced to a British journalist in the early 1990s

One might have sought the origins of this insurrection in the rise of all-powerful social media companies worth trillions and trillions,  Ambrose says.

❓ Are they not tossing lit matches into this mass of crackling-dry brushwood every day?

🗣️ Despite what youve heard, I didnt load the gun for the Capitol Hill attack , writes Ambrose Evans-Pritchard.

 The BBC wanted to tell a story about runaway conspiracies, and use me – and my reports from decades ago – as a theatre prop

🦠 Why do some people fall foul of coronavirus again and again, and others remain steadfastly immune? Is it luck or genes?

Experts stress that the science is still in progress. 

Nobody should  go around feeling Teflon-coated in some way , Professor Altmann urges. 

But as we enter our third year of the pandemic, it’s certainly a hopeful sign

Read more about the studies 👇

This possibility emerged in 2008, when virologists in Kenya found a group of sex workers who had never caught HIV, despite having unprotected sex with numerous positive cases. 

➡️It turns out their cells lacked a crucial receptor – used by HIV particles to break into our cells

🧬Another, less well-researched answer lies in our genes.

 Some people might simply be born with an immunity to certain viruses, scientists suspect.

❓But what explains this natural immunity?

The most likely theory is that these people’s immune systems have already been exposed to similar viruses, years or decades earlier.

Researchers in Britain and Brazil are looking at whether some people might possess a natural immunity to the virus. 

➡️Even before the pandemic began, their immune systems already knew how to fight the virus, it is believed

❓It’s the question on everyone’s lips.

The climate-friendliness of a food can be determined by analysing a huge range of factors, including:

❌How much power is used in making or storing it
❌How much water is used growing a crop 
❌Or, in the case of meat, cleaning a factory or farm
⚫️If you’re eating to save the planet, local, seasonal, unprocessed and plant-based foods are in; meat, dairy and water-intensive crops like avocados are likely out

🗣️ It means eating to reduce all elements that contribute to a food’s carbon footprint – which also means considering the amount of processing involved, how far it’s transported and how much of it you buy or waste,  says Dr Alona Pulde from nutrition app Lifesum

🌎It’s billed as the diet that will help save the planet – and also turn around your own health.

➡️Reframe your thoughts 

Most New Year’s resolutions are negative with built-in judgments. 

Resolutions should feel good, not tainted with what you lack

➡️Lean in to your feelings

After the events of these past months, it’s not surprising that people are still feeling worried or unsure. 

The trick here is to befriend these feelings of anxiety

➡️Mix it up

The experimentation with  who you are  – to step outside your  comfort zone  – is not to be feared, but encouraged, and we need to do more of it in 2022

People have needed a lot of mental and emotional energy to navigate this uncertainty, and it’s come at a cost.

❓The question is: are we happy with where we find ourselves as 2022 approaches?

⚡️Was Sweden right about Covid all along?

But, as Tegnell would say, it’s still too early to say – with any finality – who got it right.

🔎Read the full report here 👇
❓Do you think Sweden was right about Covid all long?

🎒Swedish schools kept going throughout, with no face masks. 

Sixth-formers and undergraduates switched to home learning, but the rest of Swedish children went to school as normal

What no statistic can convey is just how careful Swedes were; something that struck me whenever I’d visit. 

☕️It was perfectly legal to meet up in bars and for a fika in a coffee shop, but most didn’t

Nor is it possible to argue that Sweden was some hedonistic party-nation: its people were incredibly cautious. 

🤝But unlike Brits, they had a government that trusted them

As Sweden abolishes all domestic Covid restrictions, it emerges with one of Europe’s lower Covid death tolls.

Given that our death tolls were comparable at first, it’s hard to argue that there’s some demographic force which meant Covid was never going to spread in Sweden

Anders Tegnell, Sweden’s state epidemiologist, never spoke about a Swedish  experiment . 

⚫️He said all along he could not recommend a public health intervention that had never been proven

Swedes were keeping calm and carrying on: lockdown was an extreme, draconian, untested experiment.

🔑Lock up everyone, keep children out of school, suspend civil liberties – and call this  caution ?

🇸🇪Was Sweden right about Covid all along?

☕️ Read our full guide to coffee here 👇

🟤 Natural process (aka dry process’)

In this traditional method, the ripe coffee cherries’ are spread in the sun to ferment and dry for around a month, before the outside is rubbed off mechanically, leaving the beans ready for roasting & producing a fruity, full-bodied coffee

☁️ Shade grown

Coffee bushes have traditionally thrived in the shade from larger trees, but modern hybrids have been bred to be sun-tolerant, resulting in higher yields and simplification of harvest. But the biodiversity of coffee-growing areas has fallen due to deforestation

🌲 Rainforest Alliance

This certification focuses on environmental aims, in particular reducing deforestation, so coffee is likely to be shade-grown, which is better for the environment. However the auditing process is expensive for farmers

🤝 Fairtrade

Supporting small farming cooperatives in the developing world, a fair cost-of-production price is paid for goods when the beans are traded, plus a premium which goes towards community projects

🌿 Organic

No synthetic fertilisers or chemicals are used in growing or production, other than those on a permitted list. These beans have been shown to have higher levels of antioxidants especially in lighter roasts

We are bombarded by certifications, but does it really matter if it is Fairtrade, rainforest-friendly, organic? And why is coffee so contentious?

📈If the number of patients known to be waiting for treatment makes for frightening reading...

...then the unknown tally of those who have not yet come forward could be terrifying

🗓️Meanwhile 18,000 people have been waiting two years or more.

Pre-Covid, two-year waiters was a category that barely existed. Officials had promised to eradicate the list by March this year, but this week pushed back the deadline to July

⌛️Roughly speaking, one in nine of us is now formally waiting for treatment on the NHS. 

This includes more than 300,000 patients, at the last count, waiting at least a year for surgery, an almost 200-fold increase on two years ago

The scale of the mess can hardly be exaggerated. 

📈In England alone, we have over six million people – more than the population of Denmark – on waiting lists, 37 percent  more than before the pandemic

❌This time, however, the crisis is in a sense existential: at stake is the future of the health service as we have come to know it. 

In short, will we ever again be able to expect timely healthcare free on the point of demand?

🏥In the years before the pandemic, we got used to the term  NHS crisis , but mainly to describe relatively short periods of unsustainable pressure on hospitals. 

More often than not, these would start just after Christmas and last a handful of weeks

🔴The NHS backlog is arguably the most toxic indirect harm to arise from Covid and the resulting lockdowns. 

Currently it is merely a political headache for those in Whitehall, but this masks a very real and growing human crisis.

The trend for shorter singles means that music has come full circle.

Early pop and rock songs of the 1950s and 1960s also favoured brevity

📅The Beatles’ From Me To You came in at one minute and 56 seconds, one second shorter than All Shook Up by Elvis Presley

📀 Songs that are reduced in time are more favourable largely due to listener preferences, Spotify algorithms and the rise of social media platforms such as TikTok,  said a team of researchers from Harvard University

Latest Trends, a debut single, went viral on TikTok after a 15-second snippet was used in thousands of videos before the full track was even released.

🍉Last year’s winner, Watermelon Sugar by Harry Styles, was also hugely popular on TikTok and lasts two minutes and 53 seconds

But those songs are relatively drawn out in comparison to other nominees in the category 👇

🎵Bed by Joel Corry: 2:58 
🎵Friday by Riton and Nightcrawlers: 2:49
🎵Latest Trends by A1 x J1: 2:38

⏰When the category was launched in the 1980s, the average length of a nominated song was four and a half minutes.

The contenders for Song of the Year at this year’s Brit Awards include:

🎵Easy On Me by Adele: 3:44 
🎵Bad Habits by Ed Sheeran: 3:51

🎶 Why are hit songs getting shorter?

📉The average length of tracks nominated for Song of the Year at the  has fallen over the past 40 years to just 3 minutes and 7 seconds

Anne was a very spicy little girl,  said Hannah in a 1997 interview. 

Hannah’s mother would say:  God knows everything, but Anna knows everything better  – words which are repeated in the film

Hannah, also known as Hanneli and now Hannah Pick-Goslar, was immortalised as  Lies Goosens  in Anne Frank’s diary. 

In one entry, Anne sees Hannah in a dream –  clothed in rags, her face thin and worn .

Aged 93, Hannah now lives in Jerusalem. 

Her friendship with Anne is the subject of a new Dutch film titled My Best Friend Anne Frank

Soon after, Anne Frank was dead. 

Hannah Goslar survived 22 months in concentration camps.

She was hospitalised for a year afterwards and later became a nurse.

They couldn’t see each other, but spoke through the fence. 

Hannah, just 16 years old at the time, risked her life to get just a few morsels of food and a pair of socks to her best friend. 

She put them in a small package, sneaked out at night, and threw it over the fence

Hannah had been told that Anne – whom she called  Anna , her best friend since the age of four – had escaped to Switzerland. 

Now Hannah and Anne were reunited in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp – separated by a fence of barbed wire and straw

In early 1945, Hannah Goslar was unexpectedly reunited with her best friend – Anne Frank. 

Hannah was surprised. Almost three years earlier, Anne’s family had left their home in Nazi-occupied Amsterdam.

👑 The Duchess has an allied selflessness in her manner with a curiosity in – and care for – others.  What a fine Queen Consort she will make  

Read the full story 👇

💬 She asks questions, flatters you and never pulls up the drawbridge by using her royal power. 

 She is grand by being ungrand. She demands no special treatment when you’re chatting to her

⭐️ She has bucket loads of a particular charm cocktail that is popular among the more sophisticated upper classes,  writes Harry.

 It is a combination of diffidence, curiosity, humour, raffishness, teasing and self-deprecation. The only offence is to take offence

💍And then, in 2005, the couple were finally married, with the Queen’s blessing, at the Windsor Guildhall.

Ever since then, the approval ratings of the Duchess have slowly climbed to considerable levels today

In 1999, Charles and Camilla made a carefully choreographed official appearance together in 1999 at the Ritz Hotel in London.

A year later, she met the Queen for the first time since the relationship had been made public

The road to the Queen’s announcement of Camilla’s status as Queen Consort has been a long and hard one,  Harry writes.

➡️ Very slowly, thanks to a shrewd royal press office campaign, the relationship was increasingly aired to the public

Yes, she was caught up in the most famous royal scandal in living memory. 

✍️ But, as a person, there is no disingenuous scheming in her; no eye to the main chance; no carefully concealed plan to get her greedy mitts on the crown

🔴 The objective is to develop a better understanding of risk factors, which stem from individuals’ life choices, environmental factors and accessibility to healthcare and treatment,  Carlos Matius Dias says

🗣️ If whole countries had uniform levels of mortality, the maps would be in plain colours 

 Given that it is not the case, now we have to investigate and explain these differences, eliminating one factor after another,  Pablo Fernández-Navarro told The Telegraph

📊But the data from cancer of the larynx, also linked to smoking, tells a vastly different story, with a high mortality risk for men shown straddling the border in southern Portugal and south western Spain, as well as patches in the north of both countries

The lung cancer map tells a clear story of far higher levels of smoking tobacco in Spain than in Portugal

🚬Twenty per cent of Spanish adults are daily smokers, compared with just over 11 per cent in Portugal

The map shows huge differences for people living a short distance apart, sometimes across the border between Spain and Portugal, and others occurring within the same country

➡️It all points to environmental factors – as opposed to genetics – playing a role in causing cancers

💊Find out more about the five supplements that most experts agree are worth taking 👇

Heavy metal contamination, from lead and cadmium, can be an issue in non-EU brands, which are less stringently tested for safety (the UK is still operating under EU supplement laws for now), says Goggins.

💻So it’s best to avoid buying online from companies you’ve never heard of

4⃣Harmful effects

Just because they’re easy to buy, that doesn’t mean all supplements are harmless.

⚠️From 2007 to 2019, 965 products tested by the US Food and Drug Administration were found to contain hazardous ingredients

❓Does the recent trend for sprays and drops help with absorption? 

 They’re really just a marketing gimmick,  says Dr Geoffrey Mullan, a functional medicine doctor who helps clients address nutritional deficiencies. 

💊 Capsules are generally fine for most people.

3⃣Absorption

Another issue is that of absorption – are the nutrients we’re paying for ending up where they’re supposed to?

➡️Some experts have suggested that some nutrients might not be as stable in gummies and become less potent with time

🍬Gummy supplements also tend to contain fewer vitamins and minerals than pills or capsules. 

 Compared to a capsule, you’re paying for a very expensive sweet,  says Goggins

🍭We should consider supplement gums as  fortified sweets  rather than multivitamins, says Aidan Goggins, a London-based pharmacist.

 It’s the same as when you have fortified cereals or vitamin drinks and the main ingredient is sugar.

2⃣ Added sugar and sweeteners

A spoonful of sugar might make the medicine go down, but is it really justified when it comes to vitamins? 

🥄Often the first ingredient in gummy supplements is sugar or glucose syrup, with most supplements providing a gram or more per serving

🐟 Fish oil is fairly unstable,  explains Margaret Rayman, professor of nutritional medicine at Surrey University. 

 If you open the box and there’s a big, potent fishy smell, that means it hasn’t been stored properly and has gone off and you shouldn’t be taking it

1⃣ Rancid omega-3

🧠Omega-3 has been linked to brain and heart health and longevity.

Yet new research shows that more than one in 10 omega-3 supplements is rancid and half are close to the recommended maximum rancidity levels

🏗️ The remains were found after heavy machinery inadvertently removed the top of the cave last summer.
 
On-site archaeologists quickly recognised it as a significant find. Six weeks of painstaking excavation was then needed to remove the items

🤔 So how exactly were the remains preserved for tens of thousands of years?

The cave environment, which was protected from mudslides and erosion, would have shielded the remains, while the alkaline environment would have helped to prevent decay
🌄  This was a really rich and rather dry landscape. And its one that the herbivores are managing themselves. The more they graze, the more the grass grows and trees are prevented

👩‍🏫 Professor Danielle Schreve, of Royal Holloway University’s Centre for Quaternary Research, explained the significance of the original environment where the remains were found.
 
🗣️ It is what we call a non-analogue environment, this environment doesnt exist today

🕳️ The cave is believed to have been a natural pitfall that claimed the lives of multiple animals.

🦏 The remains included part of a woolly rhino, a mammoth, and a near-complete wolf skeleton.

Partial remains of a reindeer, hyena, mountain hare, and more were also found

🕰️ The subterranean trove where the preserved remains were found is believed to be around 30,000 to 60,000 years old.

👷 The trove was found during building works for a large housing estate in Sherford, outside Plymouth

🏡Just one in 10 wards in the country now have an average house price of less than £150,000.

In the North East, the proportion of wards where the average price was below £150,000 fell below 50 percent  for the first time

📉Affordability has plunged across the board. 

The number of places where homes cost less than £150,000 shrank by 28 percent  in the year to September

🔺Nationally, the number of wards where the average sale price was over £500,000 jumped by 38 percent . 

Outside London, the surge was 48 percent .

In the South West, which has seen a surge in demand from relocators following the shift to homeworking, the rise was 146 percent

Buyers have been seeking out larger, more expensive houses.

🗣️ The scale of growth in Surrey and Hertfordshire was the biggest surprise. But that is the first stop that London money makes on its way out of the capital,  said Lucian Cook

📈In Seer Green in Buckinghamshire, the average sale price in the ward jumped by £565,529 to hit £1.365m in the year to September.

In Shamley Green and Cranleigh North in Surrey, prices surged by £427,690 to £1.332m
💷In Hertfordshire and Surrey, million-pound neighbourhoods more than doubled from six to 14

➡️There are 95 wards where homes cost more than £1m, up from 80 last year, according to analysis by Savills estate agents.

New entrants to the £1m club included Lynher in north Cornwall, Bathwick in Somerset, and Frensham, Dockenfield and Tilford in Surrey

⚡️ How to work out your immunotype’ and why it could be the secret to better health

💪Dr Heather Moday stresses the importance of personalised lifestyle changes, which work with your immunotype.

Find out which immunotype you are 👇

💬 If we cut out sources of inflammation, the immune system can do its job,  says Moday.

Excess sugar, sitting too much, and drinking too much alcohol can all raise inflammation

If you are chronically inflamed, your body is already compromised, you’re putting out fires all over the place,  says Moday. 

➡️This can lead to the over-reaction of the cytokine storm’ when our immune cells’ last-ditch efforts may end on a ventilator
😷Our level of inflammation will also determine how ill we get when we are, for example, confronted with a novel virus such as Covid

🗣️ Inflammation is great as long as you can put out the fire once it’s done its job,  Moday says.

But when it keeps going or spins out of control, it can lead to dysfunction, then to chronic disease

The key lies in inflammation, part of our immune system’s repair response.

🤒When our army of immune cells is triggered this causes redness, swelling and heat, or we produce mucus to trap and expel the germs

➡️ Dr Moday believes our immune systems fall into four different types.

And working out which type you are is key to rebalancing your body’s defences against illness 🔻

🦠Modern lifestyles are fuelling a crisis in immunity, says immunologist Dr Heather Moday.

But her message is that we can all make ours more robust

🦠Is omicron becoming the common cold? History and biology may have the answer...

🦠 We suspect that the virus retreated into the background, acquiring some genetic changes along the way to facilitate its persistence in humans, to become one of four common cold-causing coronaviruses that we all periodically catch from the time we’re born to the time we die

❓So what happened in the aftermath? 

Scientists suspect the 1890 coronavirus left in its wake a herd of immune survivors who then, throughout the rest of their lives, periodically caught the virus again, but the disease was never as bad as each individual’s first encounter

✍️ The 344-page report on the outbreak, penned in 1891 by Dr Parsons’, documents strikingly similar symptoms to Covid among those afflicted, and even talks about a post-viral syndrome eerily similar to long Covid

In 1890 a pandemic swept the globe and the death toll was more than a million. 

 It was put down to flu, but, in more recent years, scientists have pieced together various lines of evidence suggesting that it was instead caused by a bovine coronavirus

😷Is the virus, in the face of the measures with which we confront it, now adapting in a more benign direction? 

 The answer is that it might be – and this is where history can help, because we have strong evidence that it’s happened before

📉So far, medics in South Africa estimate that the case fatality rate of their omicron outbreak is about 0.5 percent  compared with 3 percent  for Delta. 

 Admittedly, it’s still early days...but these data do look very encouraging  writes Dr Smith

⚡️Four ways the Russia-Ukraine war could end – from palace coup to Pyrrhic victory
Read the four scenarios in more detail here 👇

🔴Scenario four: Nuclear escalation.

Putin has already used nuclear signalling for escalation management in this crisis

🔴Scenario three: Palace coup.

A third scenario is feasible but currently unlikely, a palace coup could remove Putin from power. New Russian leaders might then negotiate a truce and prepare an orderly retreat

🔴Scenario two: Pyrrhic victory

Capturing Kyiv and achieving regime change in Ukraine remains a likely outcome. This would be a Pyrrhic victory for Russia.

But it requires heavy fighting in urban areas, killing thousands of civilians in the process

🔴Scenario one: Coercive truce

On Monday two teams of negotiators from Ukraine and Russia met for the first time in Belarus. 

But the absolute lack of trust between the parties makes this scenario hard to imagine at the moment
🔴Even though it is impossible to predict the precise political outcomes of this conflict, sketching out some possible scenarios might still help to gain clarity about policy options and risks

The French foreign ministry issued a statement saying Macron had told Joe Biden that getting over the crisis would  take time , but the healing process had begun.

Johnson has not talked to the Macron since the row. A call is yet to be scheduled

No.10 sees Aukus as part of a critical refashioning of Britain’s geopolitical strategy.
 
🌍Newly distanced from Europe, a tilt to the Indo-Pacific is under way.
 
The PM’s inner circle sees this new defence agreement as lasting decades and getting deeper and more meaningful

In the Oval Office on Tuesday, the Johnson team feared the US president could be feeling  buyer’s remorse  over the  brouhaha  from the French.
 
 They need not have worried.  @benrileysmith explains.

Biden is said to have declared straight away that the deal was the right thing

By this month, Aukus – a deliberate attempt to counter Chinese influence in the Indo-Pacific – was ready to be announced.
 
🇫🇷The French reaction was immediate and heated.
 
The deal was declared a  stab in the back ; ambassadors from US and Aus were recalled

It was behind closed doors, however, that the most meaningful interactions of the Johnson visit took place.
 
🇬🇧🇦🇺🇺🇸Most significant of all was on the new Australia-UK-US defence pact, dubbed Aukus.
 
The agreement had been months in the making

Inside the Oval Office, Johnson and Biden sat side-by-side and delivered warm opening statements.
 
⚡️There were hints at policy differences – Biden did not promise a trade deal and said he believed  very strongly  about protecting Northern Irish peace. But no fireworks

In the Fleet Street framing, prime ministerial trips abroad are often chalked up as wins or losses  writes @benrileysmith
 
On Monday, the White House announced it was dropping the travel ban.
 
✅Downing Street moved to claim victory

Johnson has had an action packed week in America:
🗓️UN General Assembly
 
🗓️Washington meeting with Biden, Harris and Congressional leadership
 
🗓️Private talks with Jeff Bezos

The course has been set for a fresh forward-leaning approach in the Indo-Pacific to counter this century’s great geostrategic challenge: A rising China.
 
🧊And the French were left on the outside.

🌍Boris’s big international gamble: how the Aukus deal was pulled off and left the French in the cold.

🇩🇪When Mrs Merkel took power in 2005, Germany was overwhelmingly white.

🔴Six years on, there has been no repeat of the Cologne sex attacks, and the jihadist threat has receded in the wake of the defeat of Islamic State.

But when more than 600 women were sexually assaulted by migrants in the Cologne New Year sex attacks at the start of 2016, she found herself politically isolated
❌Her once seemingly unassailable approval ratings collapsed, while anti-migrant sentiment fuelled a resurgence of the far-Right in the form of the Alternative for Germany party (AfD)

@MichaelPDeacons new column, Way of the World, will be published every Saturday and Tuesday in The Telegraph, starting today...
 
First up👇

It’s a daunting prospect.
 
 Not least because the news has become so relentlessly farcical that, were a time-traveller from the Fifties to pick up a copy of any paper published today, he or she might assume the entire thing was a Way of the World parody  writes @MichaelPDeacon

Waugh, in turn, was succeeded by Craig Brown, who wrote Way of the World from 2001 until 2008.
 
After that the column fell into abeyance.
 
🔴Until now!
 
@Telegraph’s parliamentary sketch writer, @MichaelPDeacon has been given the honour of reviving it

Way of the World was taken over by Auberon Waugh in the 90s.
 
30 years prior, Waugh yearned to be Wharton’s successor - In 1960, he begged Wharton to take him on: Wharton heard me out with exquisite politeness... and with the same politeness, showed me the door

The Way of the World’ column first appeared in 1955 and was initially the work of various pseudonymous hands – but, in 1957, it became the exclusive territory of Michael Wharton, writing under the name  Peter Simple .

He went on to produce four a week for the next three decades

One column, generally located towards the back - inside that single, mysterious oblong, anarchy reigned.
 
It was Michael Whartons Way of the World, its contents were a vicious, volatile, disorienting mix of the satirical and surreal…
 
And its coming back!

🇫🇷Parlez-vous Franglais? Why Boris Johnson’s hilariously annoying habit is a calculated move
Read @questingvoles 10 Franglais phrases that may come in handy  👇

🗣️ The French, bless them, are always trying their hardest not to speak Franglais. Yet their language is so littered with English loan-words that they can’t help it.  Je vais a Monaco pour le weekend,  they say.  Steak-frites,  their menus announce.

Franglais has a long and noble tradition in these isles 

🗣️ It is not failed French: Franglais is an expression of deliberate condescension. It says: look at your funny little language! Allow me to jeter you a bone  writes @questingvole

🇫🇷 By refusing to take French anger seriously it was designed to drive the prideful Macron and his garlic-chewing metropolitan allies into a state of purple-faced fury, while giving the PMs natural allies, who consider snails a pest rather than a main course, a good chuckle

But this was not the act of bumbling crassness it may have appeared. It was a very un-bumbling crassness.  

✍️ The Prime Minister’s flippant burst of Franglais was a calculating reassertion of the upper hand  writes @questingvole

🇫🇷 At once, the forlorn partisans of pro-EU social media were buzzing with outrage that a supposed statesman should be dismissing the solemn anger of a great power, should be patronising a supposed ally and, what’s more, should be doing so in Franglais.

💡Dixon says:  The fundamentals are ensuring that we have enough electrons under all conceivable sets of circumstances in order to be able to keep the lights on at reasonable prices. That therefore means gas storage, it means diversification of supply, it means greater autarky.

❓How do we fix it?

In the short-term, experts hope that big producers such as the US and Australia will respond by pumping more gas. 

 The question is whether the increase in production capacity can catch up with rising global demand levels,  analyst Tim Dixon says

Andrew Large, chairman of the Energy Intensive Users Group, said the Noughties  dash for gas  has left the country with few options beyond expensive gas.  

🗣️ Weve talked for a long time about potential grid instability due to reliance on intermittent renewables

❓Is the crisis temporary? 

Despite the prominent short-term drivers of the current spike, experts say policy decisions have also increased the UKs energy vulnerability.

Freak weather is also playing its part as droughts in Brazil and Argentina dent electricity output from their hydroelectric plants, forcing both to take up the slack in the gas market. 

📈At 164p a therm, gas prices are already around triple the average of the last decade

🇬🇧The unfavourable weather conditions have forced Britain to turn to gas to fill the gap.

But it comes at a time when demand for gas worldwide has never been higher

🌩️Pundits often reach for the hackneyed phrase of a  perfect storm  to describe a crisis...

But when renewable energy accounts for 40 percent  of electricity generation - Britains headaches are partly caused by an uncanny calm

🍃Weak winds
📉Dwindling reserves
🇪🇺Putins geopolitical tussle with Europe

These all conspire to leave the UK on the brink of an energy disaster.

⚡️The rapidly warming Mediterranean and the widening of the Suez Canal are drawing more and more non-native species into Cypriot waters

🐡 Even if we removed all the puffer fish from Cyprus waters today, in a month they will arrive from other areas. Most of these species are here to stay. 

Read the full report from @NickSquires1 in Cyprus 👇
📉 Some fishermen are saying their income has been cut by 50 percent  because of the damage done to their nets by puffer fish and the loss of their catch,  said Periklis Kleitou

🎣 Lionfish are to some extent compensating for the fact that fishermen are catching far fewer native species in the island’s waters.

But the overall impact of the arrival of exotic species has been huge

In contrast to the silver-cheeked toadfish, another new arrival in Cypriot waters is eminently eatable.

🦁The catch is that the lionfish, one of the most spectacular looking species in the ocean, is festooned with poisonous quills

🌡️Alien fish from the Indian Ocean and Red Sea are being drawn into the Mediterranean by warmer waters, caused by climate change.

This has been aided by the widening of the Suez Canal, which has changed salinity levels that previously acted as a barrier to migration

🎣 They’re very aggressive, they destroy the nets, they eat the catch inside. They are very adaptive. The species established itself really fast. They can eat anything,  said Nikolas Michailidis, from the department of fisheries

The silver-cheeked toadfish is a fisherman’s worst nightmare.

❌Not only does it prey on native species, it is also highly venomous.

📏 They grow to a length of three feet or more
⚖️ And weigh in at a chunky 20lbs

🐡The species include parrot fish, the Red Sea goat fish, the dusky spinefoot, trumpet fish and new species of sea urchins.

 Fish like this are a catastrophe for the sea,  says Loucas Georgiou, standing on the quayside of the harbour in Ayia Napa in eastern Cyprus

⚠️Cyprus is on the frontline of a marine invasion. 

🌊In recent years more than 800 species have arrived via the Suez Canal from the tropical waters of the Indian Ocean
